media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 6th October 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:04 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
00:11 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
02:19 - Introduction and Call to worship This the day that the Lord has made: Let us rejoice and be glad in it. It is good to give thanks to the Lord: For God’s love endures for ever.
03:05 - Hymn - Lord Jesus Christ
06:09 - 08:24 - Opening Prayers of adoration and confession God our Father, we have sinned against you and against one another, in thought, word and deed; we have not loved you with all our heart; we have not loved our neighbour as ourselves. But you have kept faith with us. Have mercy on us, forgive us our sins, and restore us to newness of life; through Jesus Christ our Lord. Amen. Assurance of forgiveness Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners. To all who turn to him he says: ‘Your sins are forgiven.’ He also says: ‘Follow me.’ Thanks be to God. Amen.
08:30 - 18:20 - Introduction for all ages: ‘barriers overcome’ Highlighting various "No Entry" signs as symbols of exclusion. The importance of accessibility in churches for people with disabilities Sight Loss Sunday and the need for churches to be inclusive of those with visual impairments. Hidden disabilities like hearing loss and the importance of accommodations like loop systems. Sign language is mentioned as a tool for inclusion. The concept of "walls" is explored, both physical and mental barriers that separate people. The biblical story of Jesus welcoming children is used as an example of breaking down barriers. The disciples' initial rejection of children is contrasted with Jesus' inclusive approach. The sermon concludes with Jesus rebuking the disciples and stating that the kingdom of God belongs to those like children.
#Inclusion #BreakingBarriers #Accessibility #ChurchForAll #SightLossSunday #HiddenDisabilities #SignLanguage #NoEntry #WelcomingChurch #JesusAndChildren #KingdomOfGod #Equality #Acceptance #OvercomingPrejudice #DivineLove
18:38 - 19:18 - Reading: Mark 10. 13 – 16 read by Lesley
19:46 - 21:50 - Hymn - As we are gathered Jesus is here
22:22 - 23:33 - Reading: Psalm 8 read by Ian
23:44 - 25:59 - Hebrews 1.1 – 4 and 2.5 – 12 read by Lesley
26:49 - Hymn - Be still for the presence of our Lord
29:59 - 43:32 - Short Address Reflecting on what it means to be human from a faith perspective. Psalm 8, which contrasts human insignificance with God's mindfulness of humanity. The destructive aspects of human behavior, including environmental damage and war. Jesus' welcome of children is highlighted as a radical act in its historical context. The praise of children is presented as a powerful force against evil. The psalm speaks of humanity being crowned with glory and honor by God. Jesus is described as the truest human, who has shared in human suffering. The creation of a new human family through Jesus' grace is emphasized. Being human involves recognizing our insignificance while also embracing our God-given dignity.
This sermon explores the complex nature of humanity through a Christian lens, drawing on Psalm 8 and the teachings of Jesus. It grapples with the paradox of human insignificance in the face of the universe's vastness, while also affirming the unique value and responsibility God places on humanity. The speaker addresses both the destructive capacities of humans and their potential for compassion and praise. Jesus is presented as the model of true humanity, offering a path to a new family united by divine grace. The sermon concludes by defining being human as a balance between humility before God and the honor of being part of God's creation, with the communion table serving as a symbol of this united humanity.
43:47 - 46:24 - Prayers of intercession
46:41 - Hymn - The love of God
50:17 - Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus.
Prayer of thanksgiving The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
53:09 - Distribution of communion
59:17 - Closing Prayer
01:00:23 - HYMN Now let us from this table rise
01:02:50 - 01:03:15 - Closing blessing
01:04:00 - 01:06:50 - Music after the service
#SundayInspiration #EverySunday

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 29th September 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
The service is focused on the theme of stewardship, emphasizing our responsibility to care for the planet and its inhabitants. It explores the biblical creation story and its implications for human responsibility to care for the Earth. The service acknowledges the significant environmental challenges facing our planet, such as climate change and biodiversity loss. It connects faith to stewardship, emphasizing that caring for the Earth is a Christian duty. The service encourages individuals to take action in their daily lives to reduce their environmental impact, such as recycling, conserving energy, and eating sustainably. It emphasizes the importance of collective action to address environmental challenges, including advocating for policies and practices that protect the planet. The service highlights the role of the church in promoting sustainability and concludes with a message of hope and encouragement.
Our Focus on Stewardship: We're focusing on stewardship, emphasizing our responsibility to care for the planet and its inhabitants. Creation and Our Responsibility: We're exploring the biblical creation story and its implications for our human responsibility to care for the Earth. Environmental Challenges: We're acknowledging the significant environmental challenges facing our planet, such as climate change and biodiversity loss. Faith and Stewardship: We're connecting faith to stewardship, emphasizing that caring for the Earth is a Christian duty. Individual Actions: We're encouraging individuals to take action in their daily lives to reduce their environmental impact, such as recycling, conserving energy, and eating sustainably. Community Action: We're emphasizing the importance of collective action to address environmental challenges, including advocating for policies and practices that protect the planet. Our Church's Role: We're highlighting our church's role in promoting environmental stewardship, including reducing our own carbon footprint and advocating for climate justice. Personal Reflection: We're inviting participants to reflect on their own relationship with nature and how they can live more sustainably. Hope and Action: We're concluding with a message of hope and encouragement, emphasizing that individual and collective actions can make a difference in protecting the planet.
00:00:00 - Music before the service
05:16 - Entry of the bible, welcome and lighting of the peace candle
07:07 - Welcome and call to worship
08:12 - 10:04 - Hymn - Morning has broken 45
10:15 - Intro to theme, what we will be thinking about/ policy from URC on climate change
12:24 - 16:11 - Creation readings
16:26 - 20:14 - Talk - God created us, stewardship, and our beliefs
20:15 - Break into table groups, discuss bible readings about the environment No verbal feedback but people may wish to write reflections on paper/area to share
49:31 - 52:45 - Hymn - Think of a world without any flowers-123
53:05 - 54:28 - Short prayer and Lord’s prayer
54:35 - What do we do at the moment to care for the world? Give ideas Watch presentation then discuss on tables Any new ideas?
01:12:24 - 01:15:24 - Hymn - All creatures of our God and king
01:15:37 -01:18:28 - Prayer
01:18:33 - What is stewardship of the planet What one more thing could you do? - ? Write down your commitment to that? All the little actions add up…
01:27:42 - 01:30:10 - Hymn -You shall go out with joy-415
01:30:18 - 01:30:55 - Closing blessing
01:31:17 - 01:35:05 - Music after the service
#SundayInspiration #EverySunday

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 8th September 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
02:12 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
02:23 - Welcome and Lighting of peace candle (by Duty Elder)
04:21 - Call to worship We gather today in the presence of our compassionate God, who heals and restores. Let us open our hearts to his love and grace. May our worship be a source of hope and encouragement, as we stand in solidarity with our brothers and sisters around the world.
04:49 - 07:39 - Hymn R&S 474 Brother, sister let me serve you
07:46 - Opening Prayers and The Lord’s Prayer
11:16 - 16:45 - Introduction for all ages: Let’s learn about Nepal
17:12 - 18:01 - Reading: Matthew 8. 1-4 - Jesus heals a man with leprosy read by David Bishop: When Jesus came down from the mountainside, large crowds followed him. A man with leprosy came and knelt beside him and said, ‘Lord, if you are willing, you can make me clean. Jesus reached out his hand and touched the man. ‘I am willing’, he said. ’Be clean!’ Immediately he was cleansed of his leprosy. Then Jesus said to him, See that you don’t tell anyone. But go, show yourself to the priest and offer the gift Moses commanded, as a testimony to them.
18:19 - 21:18 - Hymn R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
Junior church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing - The Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at the back of the church.
21:49 - 22:48 - Reading: Luke 17. 11-19 Jesus heals ten men with leprosy read by Valerie Bishop: Now on his way to Jerusalem, Jesus travelled along the border between Samaria and Galilee. As he was going into a village, ten men who had leprosy met him. They stood at a distance and called out in a loud voice, ‘Jesus, Master, have pity on us!. When he saw them, he said ‘Go, show yourself to the priests.’ And as they went they were cleansed. One of them, when he saw he was healed, came back in a loud voice. He threw himself at Jesus feet and thanked him – and he was a Samaritan. Jesus asked, ‘Where not all ten men cleansed? Where are the other nine? Has no one returned to give praise to God except this foreigner? Then he said to him, ‘Rise and go; your faith has made you well.
23:07 - 27:06 - Hymn R&S 92 Amazing Grace
27:32 - 48:48 - Talk by Dawn Macaulay and video followed by a time of quiet reflection
50:01 - 53:38 - Hymn R&S 274 God is love
53:49 - 58:04 - Prayers of Intercession for the World Offering prayer: Gracious God, you have blessed us beyond our deserving. You have given us more than we could ever have dared ask for, loving us with a love that refuses to count the cost, showering us with good things too many to number. Gracious God, for your generous and wonderful gifts we praise you, we give our offering as a token of our thanksgiving, in the name of Christ. Amen
59:04 - 01:03:05 - Hymn R&S 96 Great is thy faithfulness
01:03:09 - 01:03:25 - Closing blessing
01:03:57 - 01:06:28 - Music after the service
#SundayInspiration #EverySunday

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 1st September 2024
media:group.media:description:

00:00 - Music before the service

We gather here, made in the image of the Creator, who created all things in love. We gather in the name of the redeemer, our Saviour Jesus Christ, who reconciles all of Creation. We gather in the presence of the life Giver, the Holy Spirit, who inspires new life and renews our hope.

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 18th August 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
05:15 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
05:28 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
08:34 - Call to worship from Mattthew 5 Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for God’s justice, for they will be satisfied. Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God. Blessed are those who are persecuted for doing good, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven. Rejoice and be glad great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who lived before us.
09:18 - 12:49 - Hymn R&S 319 Thanks to God
12:58 - Opening Prayers and The Lord’s Prayer
15:07 - 25:33 - Introduction for all ages: ‘questions’
25:55 - 28:05 - Reading: Micah 6. 1 – 8 NIVUK read by Abigail Lokko
29:33 - 32:07 - HYMN R&S 558 Will you come and follow me?
32:19 - Introducing the readings: ‘Jesus and the prophets’
34:42 - 36:52 - Readings: Matthew 9. 10 – 13 and 12. 1 – 8 NIVUK read by Norma Garden
37:24 - 39:48 - Hosea 6. 1 – 6 NIVUK read by Terry Hinks
40:16 - 43:18 - HYMN R&S 353 There’s a wideness in God’s mercy
43:25 - 52:51 - Short Address Questions are an integral part of faith and shouldn't be denied. The Christian journey involves asking big questions without fear. Hebrew scriptures lacked punctuation, leaving room for interpretation. Questions can be asked with different intentions - some seek answers, others make points. Open-mindedness is crucial when asking questions in faith. The sermon explores various types of questions in biblical passages. God asks heartfelt questions to humanity through prophets. The prophets convey God's longing for people to return to Him. Micah's question "What does the Lord require of you?" is central to the sermon. The sermon concludes with three key actions: act justly, love mercy, and walk humbly with God.
52:57 - 54:44 - Affirmation based on Micah 4. 2 – 5 Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, to the house of the God of Jacob; that God may teach us his ways and that we may walk in his paths. God shall judge between many peoples, and shall arbitrate between strong nations They shall beat their swords into ploughshares, and their spears into pruning-hooks; nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more. All shall sit under their own vines and under their own fig trees, and no one shall make them afraid; for the mouth of the Lord of hosts has spoken. For all the peoples walk, each in the name of their god. We will walk in the name of the Lord our God for ever and ever.
56:07 - 01:04:09 - Prayers of intercession using TP 75 Peace I give to you
01:04:10 - Offering Prayer God of all life, You do not desire the sacrifice of animals or rivers of oil, but rather justice and loving kindness. So help us by your Spirit, to practice justice and fairness to love kindness and compassion and to walk each day humbly with you, our Gracious God and the God of all life. We pray in the name of Jesus. Amen.
01:05:48 - 01:08:40 - HYMN R&S 601 Christ is the world’s true light Tune: 72 Nun danket
01:08:41 - 01:09:14 - Blessing
01:09:22 - 01:11:05 - Music after the service
#SundayInspiration #EverySunday

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 11th August 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:54 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
05:07 - Welcome and Lighting of peace candle (by Duty Elder)
06:35 - Call to worship
Good Shepherd, remind us that we are your little flock, gathered by your spirit, and tended through your love. May we know your presence as we worship today. Amen
07:43 - 10:47 - Hymn R&S 552 The King of love
11:03 - 12:30 - Reading Psalm 23 A simple meditation on Psalm 23 – read by Kate Yates
12:44 - 14:40 - Prayer of Confession and Assurance of Forgiveness We come before God held in the knowledge we are loved, and with assurance that we are transformed through God’s love. Loving shepherd, we come to you to confess That there are times when we live like sheep without a shepherd. Times we allow our busyness to drive us from places of rest. Times we choose paths of discord rather than loving kindness. Times we embrace despair rather than hope Jesus is the good shepherd who has pity on his flock And promises goodness and love will be with us Follow your shepherd on the right paths, And do so in the knowledge you are loved and forgiven. Amen.
The Lord’s Prayer
14:49 - HYMN R&S 289 To God be the Glory
19:01 - 21:05 - Reading: Mark 6: 30-34, 53-56 read by Harri Bello
21:32 - Hymn R&S 197 Jesus Hands were Kind Hands
23:03 - 32:47 - Address:
32:59 - 36:11 - HYMN R&S 349 I heard the voice of Jesus say
36:20 - 39:47 - Prayers of Intercession for the World
Offering Prayer (for our gifts this last week and today)
God has gifted us everything needed for every human being on earth to have a good and fruitful life. We need only be ready to share what we ourselves have been blessed to receive. Let us pray: God, in response to your great love and generosity, we offer our gifts of money and the gift of our lives. Use them for good, as we seek to serve you and our fellow humans in love. Amen.
43:04 - HYMN R&S 549 One more step along the way I go
46:10 - 46:31 - Closing blessing
46:59 - 50:05 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 7th July 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:09 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
04:23 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:21 - Call to worship (from Isaiah 6. 1 – 8)
06:51 - 10:03 - HYMN R&S 34 Holy, Holy, Holy (Isaiah 6.3)
10:05 - Opening Prayer
11:24 - 26:03 - Introduction for all ages: ‘Collected Words’ The Bible is a collection of different writings from various times and authors. The Old Testament contains 39 books, including history, poetry, and prophecy. Prophets spoke God's word into present situations, not just predicting the future. Isaiah is considered a major prophet, with the book named after him. The Book of Isaiah is a collection of prophecies spanning over 200 years. Scholars divide Isaiah into three parts: First Isaiah, Second Isaiah, and Third Isaiah. Isaiah's wife was also a prophetess, though not mentioned by name. The Book of Isaiah is often called the "Fifth Gospel" due to its connections to Jesus. The Dead Sea Scrolls, discovered in 1946, included a complete scroll of Isaiah. Jesus read from the scroll of Isaiah in the synagogue, selecting his own passage.
26:09 - 27:09 - Reading: Luke 4.16 – 21 Good News read by Elsje Hatton
28:11 - 31:09 - HYMN R&S 591 Do not be afraid (Isaiah 41.1-4)
Junior Church continue activities in the Meeting Place (and we share a blessing – the Lord be with you; and also with you) or there are activities at back of church
34:40 - 37:03 - Reading: Isaiah 55. 1 – 13 NIVUK read by Tony Hatton
37:46 - 39:53 - HYMN R&S 415 You shall go out with joy (Isaiah 55.12) sung twice gently
40:12 - 48:10 - Short Address - Isaiah Isaiah's prophecies inspired Jesus and his followers. The book of Isaiah spans centuries and includes multiple prophetic voices. Jesus read from Isaiah in the synagogue, declaring its fulfillment in his ministry. Isaiah's words continue to inspire social justice and care for the vulnerable. The sermon references Wycombe Homeless Connection using Isaiah's words in their service. Isaiah's prophecies are seen as relevant for modern governments and society. The speaker emphasizes the enduring power of Isaiah's words across centuries. Isaiah 55 is highlighted as an invitation to seek God and find hope. The sermon notes God's thoughts and ways as higher than human understanding. It concludes with Isaiah's vision of creation rejoicing in God's redemption.
48:12 - 50:56 - Prayers of intercession World peace and justice Gratitude for compassionate people Local community organizations Political integrity Leadership for the common good Freedom for the oppressed Support for the vulnerable Homelessness and grief Illness and disability Personal intentions
Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus. When Isaiah was in the Temple and caught up in that vision of worship in heaven, he heard the voice of the Lord saying, ‘Whom shall I send and who will go for us?’
52:36 - 57:04 - HYMN MP 857 I the Lord of sea and sky (Isaiah 6.8)
57:09 - Prayer of thanksgiving
59:55 - The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
01:00:35 - Distribution of communion
01:05:36 - Closing Prayer
01:07:03 - 01:10:57 - HYMN MP 249 How lovely on the mountains (Isaiah 52.7) (popular version)
01:10:59 - 01:11:20 - Blessing (from Isaiah 58)
01:11:44 - 01:15:09 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 30th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
00:09 - Entry of the bible, welcome, lighting of the peace candle
02:23 - Call to worship: Psalm 130
03:32 - 05:45 - Hymn: R&S: 26 Father, we praise you now the night is over Tune: Christe Sanctorum
05:49 - Opening Prayers and the Lord’s Prayer
09:38 - 12:20 - Reading: Mark 5 v 21 – 43 read by Richard
12:30 - 16:39 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) Enjoying the TV show "Doc Martin" with his wife Helen. An episode where a doctor has a poor bedside manner with a sick child. A doctor with a similar bedside manner at a care home. A coroner who trained that doctor described him as "just plain odd." Discussing a story about a young girl dying. A young person's death is particularly sad and impactful. Jesus is mentioned as offering the possibility of a rich and wonderful life after death. Working with dying people and those who are bereaved. A woman who felt it was wrong that her daughter died before her. The talk concludes by discussing Jesus bringing a young girl back to life and the promise of eternal life in Heaven.
16:52 - 19:32 - Hymn: R&S: 474 Brother, sister, let me serve you
19:35 - Blessing Junior Church for their activities May the Lord be with you: and also with you. Amen.
20:57 - 23:27 - Reading: 2 Corinthians 8 v 7 – 15 read by John
23:52 - 27:13 - Hymn: R&S: 69 Lord of all being Tune: Ombersley
27:17 - Dedication of offertory
28:26 - 37:06 - Address followed by a time of quiet reflection Two healing stories from Mark 5:21-43, focusing on their interconnectedness. Mark's "sandwich" technique where one story is framed within another for emphasis. Jesus portrayed as accepting marginalized groups, including women, the sick, and the poor. The story of the woman with the issue of blood is highlighted as an example of Jesus' compassion. God's redemptive work in the midst of chaos is emphasized throughout scripture. Jesus' mission described as recovering the personhood of those marginalized by society. The church is called to challenge systems that maintain inequality and injustice. Christians are encouraged to reimagine their communities through God's love. Jesus' interaction with the woman demonstrates his protection of her dignity and identity. The sermon concludes with a call for the church to be invitational and inclusive, showing compassion to all.
37:31 - 41:22 - Hymn: R&S: 551 O for a closer walk with God Tune: Avon
41:36 - 47:03 - Prayers of intercession
47:25 - 50:52 - Hymn: R&S: 95 God is love let heaven adore him Tune: Blaenwern
50:53 - 51:14 - Closing blessing
52:05 - 54:46 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 24th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
03:28 - Entry of the bible
03:45 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
06:45 - Call to worship
08:57 - 12:42 - Hymn Praise, my soul the King of Heaven [Tune: Praise, my soul]
12:54 - Opening Prayers 15:01 - The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
16:07 - 22:20 - Introductory Talk for all ages – How do we manage when people want to do things differently to us? Managing conflicting desires between people. Examples of conflicts between a child and his grandmother. Conflict and how to manage differing wants and needs.
23:42 - 26:04 - Hymn Father, I place into your hands [Tune: Father, I place into..]
26:40 - Introduction to the readings
27:06 - 29:30 - 1st Reading: Jeremiah 10. 1 – 16 read by Linda
30:37 - 32:16 - 2nd Reading: Romans 11. 25 – 36 read by Kate
32:32 - 36:30 - Hymn Just as I am, without one plea [Tune: Saffron Waldon]
36:35 - 48:35 - Address - followed by time of quiet reflection Discussing God and worship, drawing from Old and New Testament readings. Even the chosen people of Israel struggled with proper worship. Jeremiah's role as a prophet criticizing political and religious leadership. The historical context of Jeremiah's prophecies during Babylonian rule. Drawing parallels between ancient idol worship and modern-day practices. The establishment of the church in Rome and Paul's letter to the Romans. Conflicts between Jewish and Gentile Christians in early Rome. Paul's message of continuity in God's purpose for Jews and Gentiles. Questioning Paul's explanation of God's purpose in uniting Jews and Gentiles. Emphasizing humility, loving God, and loving one's neighbor despite differences.
49:01 - 50:52 - Hymn Head of the church, our risen Lord [Tune: Melcombe]
50:58 - 55:33 - Prayers of intercession
56:01 - 59:58 - Hymn To God be the glory, [Tune: To God be the glory]
01:00:04 - 01:00:34 - Blessing
01:00:53 - 01:04:20 - Music after the service

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 16th June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
04:30 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able)
04:43 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
05:59 - Call to worship (from Psalm 104) Praise the LORD, my soul! Lord my God, how great you are! You make springs flow in the valleys, and rivers run between the hills. In the trees near by, the birds make their nests and sing. From the sky you send rain on the hills, and the earth is filled with your blessings. All creatures – and we ourselves - depend on you: when you open your hand, all are satisfied with good things.
07:22 - 10:06 - HYMN R&S 117 O Lord my God (vs. 1 and 2 only)
10:10 - Opening Prayer with the response For all your gifts and blessings: We praise you, God of all people.
17:55 - 22:34 - Introduction: ‘Elijah the outsider’
23:21 - 25:07 - Reading: 1 Kings 17. 1 – 10 read by Rosemary Taylor
25:35 - 36:30 - Talk: ‘Fed by the ravens!’ The importance of serving God, not idols or selfish interests, like Elijah served the God of Israel. The story of Elijah being fed by ravens highlights humanity's interconnectedness with nature. Questioning the belief that humans are superior to nature and can live without it. The story of the widow's unending flour and oil symbolizes God's provision in times of scarcity. The valuable role of the poor widow in helping Elijah. Jesus referenced the story of the widow, praising those who give even a cup of water. The need for recognizing interdependence and reliance on God. Jesus' teaching about God's care for even small sparrows. Praying to God as a caring, heavenly Father.
Pause: ‘Happy Father’s Day!’
36:48 - Lord’s Prayer
37:40 - 40:29 - HYMN R&S 64 I lift my eyes to the quiet hills
40:40 - 44:00 - Consider: How do you react to a crisis or a danger in your life? Do you prefer to ‘fight’ or prefer ‘flight’ or simply ‘freeze’?!
44:04 - 47:06 - Reading: 1 Kings 19.9 – 20a read by Norma Garden
47:19 - 57:44 - Reflection: ‘meeting God in the silence’ Elijah depressed and in self-pity after his triumph over the prophets of Baal. Elijah catastrophized, feeling alone and that everyone had deserted him except for God. God questioned Elijah's presence in the cave, calling him out of his despair and isolation. Rather than appearing in dramatic natural phenomena, God came to Elijah in a "gentle whisper" or "still small voice." Contrast the noise of our world with the stark silence Elijah experienced in the cave. Silence is challenging yet powerful, allowing space for God's voice amidst the inner noise of thoughts. Different translations describing God's voice as a "soft whisper," "sound of sheer silence," and "still small voice." Elijah realized he was in the presence of the holy God, covering his face in response. God met Elijah not in dramatic displays but in the stillness and quiet whisper.
Ponder: ‘We spend most of our lives focussed on three verbs: to want, to have and to do. But none of these verbs has any ultimate significance until it is transcended by and included in the fundamental verb: to be.’ (Evelyn Underhill)
58:25 - 01:00:32 - HYMN MP 48 Be still and know that I am God
01:00:59 - Further Exploration: ‘Jesus and Elijah’
01:03:26 - 01:05:53 - Reading: Matthew 17. 1 – 13 read by Terry
01:06:11 - 01:10:58 - HYMN R&S 492 Dear Lord and Father of mankind
01:11:19 - 01:18:48 - Prayers for the church and the world using verses of HYMN TP 56 Kum ba ya
01:19:04 - 01:21:59 - HYMN R&S 531 Lord of all hopefulness
01:22:00 - 01:22:17 - Blessing
01:22:47 - 01:25:31 - Music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 2nd June 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
07:49 - Entry of the Bible
07:58 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
10:01 - Call to worship
10:59 - 14:07 - HYMN R&S 102 Praise the Lord
14:08 - 16:00 - Prayer of adoration and confession
16:08 - 24:49 - Introduction for all ages: ‘Nothing like a good story’ Favourite stories, parables, and losing things
25:27 - 27:02 - Reading: Luke 15. 1 – 10 NIVUK read by Lesley Bogart
29:14 - 31:17 - HYMN CP 695 God has given us a book full of stories 31:25 - 33:06 - TP 31 Give thanks with a grateful heart (Activities for children are available during the service)
34:18 - 39:41 - Talk - Prophets The role of prophets in ancient Israel, including major and minor prophets in the Old and New Testaments. Prophets were honest truth-tellers close to God, sometimes speaking out at great personal cost. Prophecy involved discerning the signs of the times and God's wisdom, not just future predictions. There were also female prophets like Miriam, Deborah, and Isaiah's wife, though less known. The story of the prophet Nathan confronting King David over his sin with Bathsheba is examined. David abused his power by summoning Bathsheba and impregnating her, then ordering her husband Uriah's death. Nathan uses a parable to make David realize his guilt before directly accusing him. The prophets called for repentance and change, as the future was not set. David repents after Nathan's confrontation, though he still faces consequences. Prophecy involved speaking truth to power, even to kings who could have the prophet killed.
40:00 - 42:21 - Reading: 2 Samuel 12. 1 – 10 NIVUK read by Ian Bogart
43:35 - 47:37 - HYMN R&S 621 Almighty Father
47:41 - 01:00:06 - Short Address Jesus was dismissed as just a carpenter when he returned to his hometown of Nazareth, but he embraced the title of prophet. Honoring the prophets and hearing what they have to say, especially during political campaigns filled with empty words and promises. The story of the prophet Nathan confronting King David about his sin with Bathsheba is examined. Nathan uses a parable to make David realize his own guilt before directly accusing him, showing the power of stories. Prophets are called to speak truth to power, even at great personal risk. There are consequences for sin, as seen in David's family being divided by conflict after his actions. However, genuine repentance like David's leads to God's forgiveness, though consequences may still remain. A parallel between the injustice done to the poor man's lamb and the injustice of Jesus' death. Encouraging hearing the stories of the poor and marginalized in society. Despite sin and tragedy, there is hope for a new beginning through God's grace and truth.
01:01:29 - 01:06:27 - Prayers of intercession with the response Lord, may your kingdom of justice and joy come: your loving will be done.
Communion: all invited to share in the bread and wine (non-alcoholic grape juice) to remember Jesus.
01:10:29 - HYMN TP 48 Jesus calls us here
01:10:59 - 01:12:57 - Prayer of thanksgiving The Lord’s Prayer (traditional words)
01:13:04 - 01:18:56 - Distribution of communion Closing Prayer
01:19:11 - 01:21:24 - HYMN R&S 30 Father we love you
01:21:25 - 01:21:52 - Blessing
01:22:19 - 01:25:04 - Music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 26th May 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
03:21 - Entry of the Bible
03:37 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
05:48 - Call to Worship (Psalm 27. 1 – 4)
06:50 - 10:46 - HYMN R&S 121 The God of Abraham praise
11:19 - Opening Prayers Lord’s Prayer
14:16 - 17:07 - Reading: John 3. 1 – 17 read by Alan Yates
17:19 - 22:03 - Introduction to the service (All age talk) The film "Nuns on the Run" starring Robbie Coltrane and Eric Idle. In the film, two criminals disguise themselves as nuns to hide in a convent after a bank robbery. The Mother Superior allows them to stay but requires them to work like the other nuns. A humorous scene where Eric Idle's character, Sister Immaculata, tries to explain the Holy Trinity to a class of teenage girls. Sister Immaculata uses a three-leaf clover to illustrate the concept of the Trinity. A triangle, being a strong shape, can represent the strength and self-supporting nature of the Trinity. Parallels between the three sides of the triangle and the three persons of the Trinity: Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. The Trinity is a difficult concept for humans to fully understand. However, the triangle analogy can help provide a partial understanding of how God can be three persons in one. Think about the triangle next time you contemplate the Trinity, as it represents God's ability to be Father, Son, and Holy Spirit simultaneously.
22:15 - 25:47 - HYMN R&S 34 Holy, Holy, Holy Lord God Almighty
26:00 - 27:12 - Reading: Romans 8. 12 – 17 read by Kate Yates
27:31 - 34:16 - HYMN R&S 36 I bind unto myself today
34:25 - 42:58 - Address The comedy series Dad's Army and a humorous scene about choir admission forms. The ancient Athanasian Creed, which explains the doctrine of the Holy Trinity. The Creed stresses that the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are one God, yet distinct persons. The Trinity is a difficult concept for many Christians to comprehend. However, the Trinity represents a model of perfect balance, communion, and relationship within God. There is no domination or power struggle among the three persons, only absolute love. The Trinitarian relationship is meant to be an example for human relationships and love. Through Christ, believers are mysteriously drawn into this relationship of divine love. The Trinity is not just an academic doctrine but part of the believer's experience of God. The image of God as a loving Trinity is stamped into human beings from creation.
43:28 - 46:05 - HYMN R&S 38 Thou Whose Almighty word
46:10 - 51:40 - Prayers of intercession
51:59 - 54:39 - HYMN R&S 405 Angel voices ever singing
54:39 - 55:01 - Blessing
55:25 - 59:10 - Music after the service

author.name: Trinity High Wycombe and Cores End URCs

media:group.media:title: Morning Worship - Sunday, 19th May 2024
media:group.media:description:
Morning worship from Trinity United Reformed Church, High Wycombe
00:00 - Music before the service
09:45 - Entry of Bible (please stand if you are able),
10:02 - Welcome and lighting of peace candle (an elder)
12:20 - Call to worship God is Spirit: and those who worship God, must worship in spirit and in truth. God is love: and those who live in love, live in God and God lives in them. God is here: and the Spirit of Jesus is with us. Alleluia!
13:22 - 15:53 - Hymn R&S 377 This is the day
15:56 - Opening Prayer
17:09 - Introduction: ‘Hello there!’
22:51 - 23:30 - Reading: Acts 2. 1 – 4 read by Kitty Bird
24:49 - 26:59 - Hymn R&S 308 /309 Spirit of the Living God (sung seated)
27:04 - A Prayer of confession
29:46 - 32:21 - HYMN R&S 326 Loving Spirit (Tune Ellen)
32:52 - 34:08 - Reading: Acts 2. 5 – 13 read by Kitty Bird
35:16 - HYMN MP 151 For I’m building a people of power R&S 572 (MP 1039) Colours of day
39:27 - 41:01 - Reading: Acts 2. 14 – 21 read by Jeany Bien
41:12 - 52:14 - Talk: ‘God’s Spirit at work NOW’ The outpouring of the Holy Spirit on Pentecost empowered the early believers. The gift of tongues enabled the gospel to spread across language barriers. Peter boldly proclaimed Jesus as Lord and Christ, quoting Old Testament prophecies. The Spirit's outpouring was an inclusive vision for all people, men and women. The church devoted itself to the apostles' teaching, fellowship, and praise. Miraculous signs and wonders accompanied the apostles' ministry. Believers shared possessions so that no one was in need. The Spirit calls the church to speak truth, serve the needy, and welcome strangers. We should pray for the Spirit to guide our thoughts and change our ways. The church should have a vision to make the town/area a place of God's love.
52:37 - Activity: Love Wycombe and Love World
A time to share our hopes and dreams:
1. Thanks for all that is good in our town and area 2. Concerns for our town and area 3. Dreams and Vision for our town and area 4. Our part in God’s jigsaw church 5. Love for the world – Christian Aid at work
01:03:09 - An affirmation for Pentecost
01:04:19 - 01:07:02 - HYMN MP 1351 Spirit of God unseen as the wind
01:07:09 - 01:10:36 - Prayers for the church and the world and Lord’s Prayer
01:10:45 - Closing word: Birthday celebrations
01:12:16 - Holy Spirit, God with us today, fill us with your power and love. Revive your church with vision and purpose, Bring hope and healing to our community and nation. Renew the face of the earth, with peace and justice, through Jesus Christ. Amen.
01:12:49 - 01:16:58 - HYMN MP 664 The Spirit lives
01:16:59 - 01:17:19 - BlessingThe outpouring of the Holy Spirit on Pentecost empowered the early believers. The gift of tongues enabled the gospel to spread across language barriers. Peter boldly proclaimed Jesus as Lord and Christ, quoting Old Testament prophecies. The Spirit's outpouring was an inclusive vision for all people, men and women. The church devoted itself to the apostles' teaching, fellowship, and praise. Miraculous signs and wonders accompanied the apostles' ministry. Believers shared possessions so that no one was in need. The Spirit calls the church to speak truth, serve the needy, and welcome strangers. We should pray for the Spirit to guide our thoughts and change our ways. The church should have a vision to make the town/area a place of God's love.
01:17:49 - 01:23:20 - Music after the service
